Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial funding for a monograph on the role of ice in clouds. Ice crystals play an important role in the formation, evolution and impact of clouds on weather and climate. The monograph is a summary of the scientific field's current state of understanding of how ice forms and evolves and of our technological capability to measure the critical properties of these ice crystals. Broad dissemination of the results of past research and workshops will help the community to guide future research that is necessary in ice microphysics.

The monograph, titled "Ice Formation and Evolution in Clouds and Precipitation: Measurement and Modeling Challenges," has 5 primary objectives: 1) To summarize our current understanding of ice evolution in clouds, from first ice formation to removal by precipitation, melting, evaporation or sublimation, 2) To identify those processes in ice formation and evolution that are not well understood, and highlight the impacts of those knowledge gaps on the ability to forecast weather, predict future climate, understand cloud electrification, and aviation hazards, 3) To assess current and new measurement systems that characterize ice particle properties and of models that diagnose or prognose ice evolution, 4) To evaluate and compare methodologies used for processing measurements of cloud properties and recommend best practices that minimize uncertainties and maximize extracted information, 5) To formulate a list of recommended actions that can and should be implemented to improve our understanding of ice evolution in cloud.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project brought together nearly 30 international atmospheric scientist to write an American Meteorological Society (AMS) monograph entitled "Ice Formation in Clouds and Precipitation: Measurement and Modeling Challenges". Contained in 11 chapters are detailed overviews of the most recent science of ice in clouds and modern technology for measuring cloud ice properties and the ice nuclei (IN) from which it forms. The authors are active researchers from universiies, research institutes and government laboratories; hence, all the information is current up to the time of publication.

 

Broader impacts: The monograph is writen at the college level of science understanding. The intent is to educate students at undergraduate and graduate understanding while containing advanced information that will provide graduate students and researchers sufficient background information and detail to help frame the outstanding questions that remain to be understood. Each chapter ends with a list of these questions accompanied by recommended actions. These recommendations are clearly elucidated to assist researchers in writing proposal for research grants that can address the questions that remain as obstacles to our understanding of the basic microphysical processes and their impact on weather, climate and society.

Summary: An 11 chapter monograph on the theory of ice formation in clouds, and our current understanding based on in situ and remote sensing measurements, has been published with the help of NSF funding. Written by a who's who list of international experts in cloud measurements and modeling, this book will be a reference text to the atmospheric community for many years to come. Students, technical personnel and research scientists will find answers to questions about how ice forms, how to measure its properties and what are the limitations and uncertainties in these measurements. The extensive list of references allows researchers to delve deeper into the subject matter while laying out the future with respect to what remains unknown and what steps are needed to resolve the outstandig questions.
